newsitem.title: UK: Markets wait to pounce on unguarded EMU comments.
newsitem.headline: Markets wait to pounce on unguarded EMU comments.

text.p: Financial markets are lying in wait for Europe's policy-makers, ready to pounce on any unguarded comments as golden money-making opportunities.
And right now, the vexed question of European economic and monetary union (EMU) is the biggest money-spinner of all.
Politicians across Europe winced on Friday when Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi said it was possible Germany might request a delay to EMU. And the market's reaction?
"Delighted -- a chance to make some money," said David Coleman, chief economist at CIBC Wood Gundy in London.
The lira and Italian bonds, already hurt by speculation of EMU delay, racked up yet more losses after Prodi's remark.

"There's no doubt politicians are in an extremely difficult position," said Coleman. "Publicly, they have to keep plugging the view that everything's fine in the garden, it will all come out right in the end, but privately they must have some doubts."

On a purely technical basis, traders and analysts say, there was clearly room for some unwinding of the popular convergence plays -- based on the premise that EMU will proceed as planned in 1999 -- which have swept the market for the best part of a year.

"The only reason for being long the peripheral currencies is a strong belief that EMU will start on time, and once that is in doubt, the whole edifice in the forex markets begins to crumble," said an analyst at a British bank here.
Bond yield spreads tell the story vividly. In January of this year, 10-year Italian debt yielded around 170 basis points over German, with Spain's premium over Germany near 100.
That was effectively discounting Italian and Spanish EMU participation, and left the market hyper-exposed to news or official comments casting doubt on that scenario, analysts said.

"At the beginning of the year there was widespread optimism that the political momentum behind EMU was very strong, and the wider membership story was a prevalent one and a very realistic one," said Ken Wattret, economist at Banque Paribas.
"Within a month, we've seen divergence re-emerge and if anything we'd be looking for the situation to be biased towards continued divergence from here."
Italy's spread over Germany swelled to 201 basis points on Monday, its widest since November, with Spain's at 138.
Prodi swiftly "clarified" Friday's EMU-delay comment by saying there was no assumption the timetable would be put back.
German foreign minister Klaus Kinkel backed that on Sunday, attacking market speculation of EMU delay and saying "opponents of the euro are continuing their irresponsible actions".
On Monday, Bundesbank president Hans Tietmeyer called talk of delay "nonsense", while European Monetary Institute chief Alexandre Lamfalussy said the speculation was unfounded.
But official rebukes cut little ice with the markets.

"For short-term traders, people who probably don't look at those currencies on a day-to-day basis, what makes sense is they jump on the bandwagon early and make some money," said Peter Wood, forex trader at Bank of Boston here.
Economic realities also give the lie to political pronouncements that monetary union is on track, say analysts.

Foremost in the market's mind is the dire economic situation in EMU-lynchpin Germany. Bild am Sonntag newspaper reported on Sunday that February unemployment rose by 120,000 to a new postwar record of 4.8 million, a rate of 12.5 percent.
And despite the chorus of denials which greet comments such as Prodi's, the market is growing suspicious of a covert campaign to soften it up for an announcement of EMU delay.

"There's no smoke without fire," said CIBC's Coleman. "I think there's a fair amount of truth behind the view that either Italy will have to be convinced to step out of the project or that the whole project itself will be delayed."
